item.title: Progressive web application as a share option in Android
item.dc:creator: Jakub Chodounsky
item.content:encoded:
Progressive Web Applications are becoming more and more powerful and now can be registered as a share intent on Android devices. This means that any Android application can share directly to your web app through the standard native sharingÂ dialog.

It also works the other way around. Your PWA can trigger the native share dialog and send data to other applications. This brings them one step closer to nativeÂ apps.

In this article we will focus on becoming the shareÂ target.

Can a progressive web app be registered as a share option inÂ Android?

For a long time this wasnâ€™t an option. But with the release of Chrome 71 on Android there is an experimental support of the Web Share Target API. Your PWA can appear in the sharing menu. How cool isÂ that?

Letâ€™s have a look at what you need to get your website into the Android sharingÂ dialog:

  1. Manifest
  2. Service Worker
  3. Share target

If you like this type of content, check out React Digest, a weekly newsletter with 5 hand-curated top quality articles.

Becoming progressive

The first steps are really about becoming a progressive web application. The share intent will be registered when the user â€œinstallsâ€ the app by saving it to the home screenâ€Šâ€”â€Šeither from a popup or manually.

Important note: Your website needs to be served overÂ HTTPS.

For that you will need a website manifest and a registered service worker. Firstly, letâ€™s have a look at a simple manifest.json.

{
  "short_name": "Sharing Demo",
  "name": "Web Target Sharing Demo",
  "icons": [
    {
      "src": "/android-chrome-192x192.png",
      "type": "image/png",
      "sizes": "192x192"
    },
    {
      "src": "/android-chrome-512x512.png",
      "type": "image/png",
      "sizes": "512x512"
    }
  ],
  "start_url": "/",
  "background_color": "#ffffff",
  "display": "standalone",
  "theme_color": "#ffffff"
}

You can read about all the different values and options in more detail here. After that, we will need to link to our manifest in our HTML files. So add the following into head section of yourÂ page.

<link rel="manifest" href="/manifest.json">

The Second thing for an app to become a PWA is a registered service worker with a fetch event. It doesnâ€™t need to do much, it just has to be there. The simplest way to do that is to create service-worker.js with an empty fetch listener.

self.addEventListener('fetch', function(event) {});

It wonâ€™t do anything but it is everything we need for now. Next, we will register the service worker in ourÂ page.

if ('serviceWorker' in navigator) {
    navigator.serviceWorker.register('/service-worker.js')
      .then(function(reg){
        console.log("Service worker registered.");
     }).catch(function(err) {
        console.log("Service worker not registered. This happened:", err)
    });
 }

Nice work! It wasnâ€™t too hard and we changed a simple website into a progressive web app. If you are using HTTPS you should be able to see the Add to home screen popup when you visit yourÂ website.

You can use Chrome Dev Tools to check on the manifest and see if the app can be installed. Go to Application -> Manifest or use Lighthouse and see the Installable section of theÂ report.

Converting your website to a progressive web application was actually the hard part. Registering the share intent so your app will appear in the native dialog is superÂ easy.

You need to add the following lines into your manifest.json that we created previously.

"share_target":
  {
    "action": "/share",
    "params":
    {
      "title": "title",
      "text": "text",
      "url": "url"
    }
  },

Every time a user will share something through the dialog the request will go to /share endpoint of your website with query parameters of title, text, andÂ url.

Note: If you are sharing something from mobile Chrome the URL actually comes through as aÂ text.

Now we put everything together and this is the final version of the manifest.json file with registered share_target section.

{
  "short_name": "Sharing Demo",
  "name": "Web Target Sharing Demo",
  "icons": [
    {
      "src": "/android-chrome-192x192.png",
      "type": "image/png",
      "sizes": "192x192"
    },
    {
      "src": "/android-chrome-512x512.png",
      "type": "image/png",
      "sizes": "512x512"
    }
  ],
  "share_target":
  {
    "action": "/share",
    "params":
    {
      "title": "title",
      "text": "text",
      "url": "url"
    }
  },
  "start_url": "/",
  "background_color": "#ffffff",
  "display": "standalone",
  "theme_color": "#ffffff"
}

After that, you can use any method of reading the query parameters that suits your needs. Either server-side like this with Ruby onÂ Rails:

def share
  @url = params[:url]
  @title = params[:title]
  @text = params[:text]
end

or client-side with a bit of good old javascript:

var parsedUrl = new URL(window.location.toString());
console.log('Title shared: ' + parsedUrl.searchParams.get('name'));
console.log('Text shared: ' + parsedUrl.searchParams.get('description'));
console.log('URL shared: ' + parsedUrl.searchParams.get('link'));

Iâ€™m a big fan of progressive web apps and the web share target makes the integration with your mobile workflow much smoother. It comes with a few caveats of being experimental so the API will most likely change or it could totally disappear. Also, keep in mind that (at the moment) itâ€™s supported only on Android devices and your Apple users wonâ€™t benefit from itÂ . The proposal takes iOS into account though so maybe some time in the future. Iâ€™ve been waiting for this feature for a while and Iâ€™m super-excited that it made it to the Android community.

If you liked this article and you are a React Developer, check out React Digestâ€Šâ€”â€Ša weekly newsletter that will keep you up toÂ date.

Originally published at chodounsky.net on March 24,Â 2019.

item.title: C# â€” good career choice or not?
item.dc:creator: Jakub Chodounsky
item.content:encoded:
If you are just starting out or you are a seasoned developer with battle scars and years of experience under your belt you asked yourself this question at least once: is C# a good careerÂ choice?

Well, letâ€™s try to answer it as objectively as we can. At times you can replace C# withÂ .NET ecosystem as aÂ whole.

Variety

C# andÂ .NET framework is one of the most versatile tools for software developers. You donâ€™t have to jump across different stacks to get more exposure to different platforms.

You have two great frameworks for creating web applicationsâ€Šâ€”â€ŠASP.NET and ASP.NET MVC. The tooling and the speed of development is on par with the most advanced frameworks in other languages. The biggest competition in this area would be without any doubts Ruby onÂ Rails.

With Xamarin being acquired by Microsoft the state of mobile development for the major platforms is at a great stage. There is a huge benefit of maintaining a codebase in one language and having shared libraries across the Android and iOS platforms. With C# you can do all of that. Other major players in this area are React Native backed by Facebook but some of my mobile developer friends would swear on the native platform development.

Microsoftâ€™s cloud platform, Azure, is growing fast and offers various tools not just for your backend API code and storage, but also for background jobs, machine learning, various cognitive services, enterprise solutions and security and identity management. There is a lot of goodies there that could make your developerâ€™s life easier. Not to forget to mention that if you are a MSDN subscriber, you get a free credit to try themÂ all.

When you need a thick client; a desktop application; it will be usually targeted towards Windows. You canâ€™t really get a better framework for getting the job done than WPF or the simplicity of WinForms. There is not a lot of innovation in the field but those frameworks are far from being dead. They are the steady workhorse that is easy to use and does theÂ job.

Lastly and slightly unexpectedly, there is a large camp of game developers. Unityâ€Šâ€”â€Šone of the biggest 3D engines uses C# as a language of choice and the tooling in Visual Studio gets better with every newÂ version.

C# gives you a great variety of applications that you can create and you donâ€™t need to learn new libraries and language constructs. You can write web applications in Lisp or Smalltalk and create Android applications in Ruby but that doesnâ€™t mean that you should. C# on the other hand is one of the best tools for the job in any given category.

Technical

C# is an object oriented imperative languageâ€Šâ€”â€Šyou tell the computer what to do and can wrap those commands into objects modelling your desired world. This paradigm is the most widely used nowadays and therefore a good one to master. Applications patterns and object oriented practices are transferable to many other platforms and languages.

But apart from that, C# also has a number of features from functional languages. You donâ€™t get tail-recursion, but LINQ is a brilliant tool for data transformation and filtering. And with C# 7.0 you get pattern matching as well. So you can expand your skills with other paradigms without leaving your favourite language.

Apart from that, C# is statically typed. That gives you an amazing tool when working on bigger projects with larger team and you realise how helpful it is when you find yourself in this situation in a dynamically typed languages likeÂ Ruby.

Also, there are dynamic features of C#. The dynamic keyword and reflection API gives you powerful tools to create nice DSLs or effectively work with JSON APIs. With great power comes also great responsibility and you shouldnâ€™t use them mindlessly, but you have that tool in yourÂ toolbox.

If this article convinces you that C# is a good career choice check out C# Digest weekly newsletter to stay up to date withÂ .NET community.

Experience

One of the biggest advantages of C# is that it is used amongst the wide spectrum of companies. From small startups to giant corporations.

Each type of company has a different set of challenges and problems so I recommend every programmer to go through each type in their career. Even if you think you are not made for a big corporation, working for one gives you a decent perspective on what these companies are struggling with.

And on the other end of the spectrum startup sized company doesnâ€™t need to be 80 hours per week work, but you will have to step into more breadth of rolesâ€Šâ€”â€Šdevops, technical support and a green field development.

Gaining exposure to various businesses is possible with C# without relearning the framework and language and you can focus more on the domain and team dynamicsÂ instead.

Try to find a huge corporation using Rubyâ€Šâ€”â€Šnot thatÂ easy.

Money and Stability

Letâ€™s be honest. We work because we need to earn our living. And with C# you have solid prospects. Big finance corporations are using C# as their stack of choice which guarantees salaries on the higher end of the spectrum.

You can always earn more cheddar by being a specialised COBOL contractor, SAP consultant or do whatever the current hotness is, but as a software developer that wants to have wide exposure and the ability to move across companies and types of applications you are getting one of the best deals on theÂ market.

Add a solid foundation of good old SQL and you can mine that skillset for the next few decades of mortgage driven development.

Apart from that, there is plenty job opportunities in C# in most places around the world which gives you desired stability and option to change in case your current company gets into troubles.

Microsoft

Microsoft used to be this evil closed company that wanted to get all the profits (honestly, show me a company that doesnâ€™t) at all cost that all the technical people made fun of and prefer not to touch Windows Vista even with a long stick. But the times are changing, especially for developers.

C# andÂ .NET framework with the Roslyn compiler are open-sourced and hosted onÂ Github.

.NET Core runs on many other platforms than just Windows and we have Visual Studio for Mac and lightweight Visual Studio Code that runs almost everywhere.

There is a great team behind C# language pushing the innovation forwards and the Cloud and Enterprise division under Scott Guthrie is thriving. One clear direction behind the product is important.

Windows has a bash now and runs Ubuntu and plan to add Fedora andÂ SUSE.

Exciting times for C# developers!

Competition

Letâ€™s discuss other platforms and their strengths and weaknesses.

What about Java? Java is pretty much similar to C#â€Šâ€”â€Šall the benefits are there. You might get better tooling and more support for some trendy machine learning and big data frameworks but you wonâ€™t be building nice desktop clients for Windows. Also, the language standard and the language features are a bit behind C#. In overall, not a bad career choiceÂ either.

When talking about Ruby, you can honestly replace it with Ruby on Rails, as the vast majority of Ruby jobs are Rails jobs. It dominated in the web startup world in the past decade. Other web frameworks caught up, but you have a lot of successful small to medium businesses built on top of Rails that needs development and maintenance. It is a good choice for startups where you want to move fast but donâ€™t want to grow the team too much. It is a great choice if you want to work a remotlyâ€Šâ€”â€Šthere is far more options than in any other language. But the job market might be limited in your area and you will be building CRUD webÂ apps.

Javascript is currently high in demand. It is easy to get into and you can write backend with Node.js, desktop applications with Electron and mobile apps with React Native. Javascript wasnâ€™t made for maintaining a large codebase and the ever changing world of front-end framework gets tiring. And lots of times it is just reinventing the wheel again. But if you are in web stack you will need to have some exposure to it anyway. Iâ€™d use it as a secondary language for front-end heavy web applications.

What other platforms and languages would you consider and how would they compare toÂ C#?

Conclusion

To sum it up, you will have a great career if you decide to choose C# as a language of choice. The biggest benefit is the variety of applications you can work on and companies that useÂ C#.

It will give you great job stability and salaries that are on the higher end of theÂ market.

Lastly, C# is cool and fun to work withâ€Šâ€”â€Šyou can always learn a new thing and Visual Studio will be your reliable buddy helping on the big projects with IntelliSense.

In overall, exquisite choiceÂ sir.

Do you want to become a better C# developer? Subscribe to C# Digest and stay up to date within theÂ .NETÂ world.

item.title: How to keep up to date as a C# developer
item.dc:creator: Jakub Chodounsky
item.content:encoded:
As a developer, I bet you have a life long passion for learning and with the technology, there is always something exciting going on right now. Thus, how do you navigate in this world of constant change and keep up to date with news, which matters to a smart C# developer?

Blogs

There are plenty of great blogs about various topics related to C# but you donâ€™t have to get too far away from good old MSDNÂ blogs.

The Visual StudioÂ Blog

Most of the C# developers use Visual Studio. It is great to have IDE and the Visual Studio team blogs regularly about new features, plugins and tips, which will make you more productive.

.NET Blog

Wanna see whatâ€™s new with the core platform? Follow this blog and you wonâ€™t miss anything related toÂ .NET Framework.

.NET Web Development and ToolsÂ Blog

If Web is your main domain, you want to follow ASP.NET team and what they are working on. Recently, they started publishing their weekly standups with the notes, which gives you a sneak peek into how the platform is being developed. Nowadays, following a single blog is not the best strategy to get your news. There are lot of interesting blogs and articles and you need to be subscribed to numerous RSS feeds. Selecting what to read will be time consuming and this brings me to the nextÂ section.

Newsletters

Newsletters are a medium, where someone else takes the time to curate the content for you. The traditional ones will land into your inbox on the periodical basis and there are few in a form of aÂ blog.

Disclaimer: I curate C# and Programming Digestsâ€Šâ€”â€Šif you know of any otherÂ .NET newsletters, please mention them in the comments.

C# Digest

C# Digest is a weekly newsletter, which sends you only five carefully selected links every Monday. Just five? But they are the top-notch. If you want to follow only one source, this would be itâ€Šâ€”â€Šone article for each working day. There is lot of love and hard work behind the content curation.

The MorningÂ Brew

Every morning Chris Alcock sends an update of what happened in the world ofÂ .NET Web development. He is mostly focused on ASP.NET and the world of Javascript.

Alvin Ashcraftâ€™s MorningÂ Dew

Alvin Ashcraft puts together a daily list of more well-rounded resources than Chris. You can find news on WPF, databases, Powershell, development methodologies and Web programming.

Programming Digest

This is a similar format to C# Digest but the theme is more of a general programming. Thus, if you want to keep an eye on what is happening outside Microsoft world, this one would be a perfect to add to the mix. Again, only five high quality links weekly to yourÂ inbox.

Podcasts

I love listening to programming podcasts, as I can do it during my daily commute, exercising or even house chores. The information density is not that high but you canâ€™t really read a book while vacuuming, right?

.NET Rocks!

Richard and Carl are not just awesome interviewers but also funny entertainers.Â .NET Rocks! has been around for ages and not justÂ .NET programmers listen to it. Thatâ€™s how good itÂ is.

Hanselminutes

Scott Hanselman is a big name in the ASP.NET community but his podcasts are often way beyond just that. Every guest is so interesting that you donâ€™t want to miss anÂ episode.

Channel 9

For me personally, video doesnâ€™t work that well, as other media but Channel 9 has been recommended to me multiple times as a free source of talks and interviews from Microsoft world.

Communities

Donâ€™t underestimate the power of conversations. Many times, I found myself talking to a stranger atÂ .NET meetup that pointed me to a few excellent resources and told me whatâ€™s going on in his field of work. Content curation and digestion in real time is underrated.

Meetup

Meetup is a great site to find a localÂ .NET user group. It is popular in lots of countries and if by any chance, your one is not there, Iâ€™m pretty sure there is a local alternative to it. Hence, just use Google and start participating.

I live in Wellington, New Zealand and it has a very active WellingtonÂ .NET User Group with regular talks and pizzaâ€Šâ€”â€ŠBevan is doing an excellent job of runningÂ it.

Reddit

Reddit is a classic in the technology sphere. The /r/csharp is a source of interesting links and interesting questions with answers, ranging from beginners to experts. As it could be an opposite in other subreddits, beginners are treated fair with respect here and moderators are doing a amazing job of keeping the content relevant.

Discord

Discord is quite new to me, but Iâ€™ve heard, it is super popular amongst gamers. It is a Slack on steroids and there is a thriving C# community, which is very helpful and would love to have you as aÂ member.

And what about you? What resources do you follow? What is your preferred way to stay up toÂ date?

This article was originally published on C#Â Corner.

item.title: 5 books every C# developer should read
item.dc:creator: Jakub Chodounsky
item.content:encoded:
A list of the 5 most influential books that changed my perspective on programming.

Some people like to watch courses, others like to tinker with the code, but I like to read. Books about programming are a bit tough sell though. Dry, long, and they become obsolete quickly. But you can find rare gems that donâ€™t fit that boring category.

These following books helped to advance my career and change the way how I build software.

CLR viaÂ C#

For a C# developer this should be a bible. It is long, it is detailed, but Jeff Richter is doing a great job of keeping the reader engaged. You are going to deep dive into the nitty gritty details of theÂ .NET framework and C# and when you are done with the book yourÂ .NET skills will increase by at least 1000Â points.

Please, read this book and make theÂ .NET world a betterÂ place.

Domain-Driven Design

In this book, Eric Evans dives deep into the design of complex systems. It has an academic feel and there is a lot of theory, naming and repetition. But it is worthÂ it.

The focus on speaking the same language as your business experts is a revelation. Learn business terms and understand the concepts in your domain. And when you start using that language in your code it is a true transformation to a self-documented maintainable piece of software.

Threading inÂ C#

A free chapter from Joseph Albahari C# in Nutshell book that has the best explanation of threading, synchronisation and advanced parallel techniques in C# I everÂ read.

Itâ€™s a must read before you type new Thread(â€¦) into VisualÂ Studio.

The Passionate Programmer

As opposed to the other pieces in this list Chad Fowler doesnâ€™t directly focus on creating software. The main focus is how to grow your software developer career and how to approach it as a business.

For me the biggest takeaway from the book was understanding the impact of your work on the bottom-line of the company. In other words, how much money your codeÂ makes.

And also, as a software developer you need to build other skills than just hardcore coding. Marketing, networking, communication amongÂ others.

Practical Object-Oriented Design inÂ Ruby

Wait a minute. This book is not about C# at all. What is it doing on theÂ list?

Yeah, it is in Ruby, but Sandi Metz is one of those developers that grew up with Kent Beck and went through the classic Smalltalk object oriented designÂ school.

She has a talent for explaining hard design concepts with simple words. After reading this book, design of my objects improved dramatically and for me itâ€™s the most influential piece I read on object oriented programming.

Conclusion

Firstly, if you liked the books mentioned above chances are that you might enjoy my weekly C# Digest newsletter.

There are so many technical books on the market but if you would read just these 5 from cover to cover youâ€™d gain an exceptional knowledge and have a solid background to become a greatÂ .NET developer.

And now over to you, dear readerâ€Šâ€”â€Šwhich software books make it to your topÂ 5?

item.title: C# 7.0 and Beyond with Mads Torgersen
item.dc:creator: Jakub Chodounsky
item.content:encoded:
New Zealand and Wellington especially are not exactly big so when the program manager of C# language comes into town for a meetup it would be a shame to stay atÂ home.

This Wednesday the amazing WelliDotNet meetup hosted Mads Torgersen; a guy responsible for the C# language design (and TypeScript and Visual Basic in the past); and he talked about the new features of C# 7.0 and where the next versions areÂ heading.

Mads started with the results of Stack Overflow Developer Survey 2017 results where C# is 4th most used programming language.

And it also made it to the top 10 most loved programming languages.

He thinks the reasons behind thatÂ are

  • C# now runs on every platform (not just Windows),
  • Roslyn is an open compiler,
  • you can use your favourite editor, not just Visual StudioÂ and
  • everything is openÂ source.
Q: How hard was it to get more open?
A: It was hard initially and was happening more on team level. Now it aligns with the overall vision of Microsoft and how products interact with each other (e.g.Â Azure).

C# evolution is a balancing act as you wantÂ to

  • aggressively improve and also stayÂ simple,
  • improve existing development and become attractive to moreÂ users,
  • embrace new paradigms but stay true to the spirit ofÂ C#.

New features in C#Â 7.0

Mads started with minor features and talked briefly about new binary literals. And the _ separator.

int[] x = [0b1, 0b10, 0b100, 0b1_000];
int y = 1_000_000;
Q: How does C# 7.0 relates to the CLR? Does it need an updated runtime?
A: You can target CLR 2.0â€Šâ€”â€Šno new feature is implemented with new IL instructions.

Tuples

One of the major features is the direct support of tuplesâ€Šâ€”â€ŠSystem.ValueTuple. So now you can write functions with multiple returnÂ values.

private static (int, int) Tally(int[] numbers)
Q: How is System.ValueTuple different from System.Tuple?
A: It is a struct as opposed to System.Tuple being class. And it has just 7 fields and the rest becomes a tuple (e.g. Item8 is aÂ tuple).
Q: Why is System.Tuple class?
A: It was a design decision from F# teamâ€Šâ€”â€Šbut they might regret it asÂ well.

Also, you can write tuple literals like(0,Â 0);

Q: Is that limited to value types only?
A: No, they are generic types underneath.

You can optionally provide names for tuple items in method definitions, literals and everywhere else you useÂ tuples.

public static (int sum, int count) â€¦
var x = (sum: 0, count: 0);

These names are tracked only by the compiler; in runtime they are not used and only Item1 style is visible. In debugging the names are available but not if you use reflection.

Another feature is deconstruction of tuples with _ notation for unused variablesâ€Šâ€”â€Šdiscards.

(int sum, _ ) = Tally(numbers);

The deconstruction could be also used with your own types overriding the deconstructor.

Tuples are mutable but it is discouraged to mutate themâ€Šâ€”â€Šitems are public fields which mitigates every downsides though. You get equality, hashcode computation and all the benefits of using structs out of theÂ box.

Local functions

Apart tuples you can write local functionsâ€Šâ€”â€Šfunction inside a function. It could improve readability of your code while keeping it closed and nicely contained.

private void MyFunction()
{
    Add(0, 1);
    void Add(int s, int c => r = (â€¦.);
}
Q: Can you pass local function as a lambda delegate to other function?
A: Yes, youÂ can.

Pattern matching

C# finally gets pattern matching in a slightly awkwardÂ syntax.

switch (v)
{
  case int i:
    Add(i);
    break;
  case object[] a when a.length > 0:
    ...
}
Q: Is there a plan for better matching syntax?
A: Yes, it is on theÂ agenda.

Note that you can use any condition expressions and itâ€™s capable of extracting the value matched to the â€œlocalâ€ variable. With that feature switch is now case sensitive.

Q: Is this a breaking change?
A: No, because the previous switch expressions were using constants which didnâ€™t care about theÂ order.

Others

And with that a few other smaller features. You can declare variable in the middle of expression.

int.TryParse(â€¦, out var x) { x += 1; }

And you can do ref returns and ref locals. Which is useful for low level development where you donâ€™t want to allocate objects and want to avoid garbage collection.

The future

New versions of C# are planned to be released on quarterly basis which sounds quite daring. The next proposals are just drafts and could be changed in theÂ future.

C# 7.1

This should be a release of minor convenience features that are not really related to each other, are small and self-contained.

Being able to define async Main function even if it is mostly for demonstration purposes.

And explicitly state default initialisation with

int i = default

enhance the null inference

int? n = b ? i : null

add tuple projection initialisers

var t = (i, n); return t.i;

and add discards to moreÂ places

o.PropertyChanged(_, _) => â€¦

C# 7.2

This release will focus on more low level stuff without the need to work with pointers. There is a lot of game developers using C# with Unity and better performance could also be used in finance and other applications.

Those features could include ref readonly parameters and returns (the opposite of out parameter which needs to be assigned)â€Šâ€”â€Šit says donâ€™t modifyÂ me.

The extension methods are not ideal so redesign them and allow them to be used with refs and onÂ structs.

And allow ref conditionals.

Another feature could include readonly structs that donâ€™t need to be copied and a new ref-like structures for abstraction over a chunk ofÂ memory.

C# 7.3

This version should focus on nicer patterns and developerâ€™s user experience. That could involve better recursive patterns, nicer syntax for pattern matching and tuple patterns.

C# 8.0

Major release in which the C# team might introduce changes to CLRâ€Šâ€”â€Šthat would be for the first time since the introduction of generics. All the features added since were mostly compilerÂ tricks.

One proposed feature are nullable reference types.

string? n; // nullable â€” enforces checking before usage
string s; // non-nullable
n = null; // sure
s = null; // warning
s = n; // warning
s.Length(); // sure
n.Length(); // warning
if (n != null) { n.length } // sure
n!.length // sure â€“ a new operator converts into non-nullable

Big feature could be adding default implementation to interface members. One of the use cases would be making C# a great tool for working with mobile platforms (both Java and Objective-C supports this feature) and make Xamarin even moreÂ awesome.

And lastly a few improvements around async with async streams and disposables and adding foreach await to process data when coming and using await for safe application of disposable pattern.

C# could add records (similar to Rubyâ€™s OpenStruct) for simple classes with default implementation of deconstruction, hash codes and equality.

class Person(string name, string lastName);

Lastly, there might be a support for immutable objects.

Conclusion

So thatâ€™s it. The future for C# is pretty bright and the features are exciting. Iâ€™m quite happy about pattern matching introduction and deconstruction. And maybe in the future immutable objects with some nullable reference types. Thatâ€™d beÂ cool.

Again, big shoutout to WelliDotNet not just for the pizza but for the great event with the world classÂ speaker.

item.title: Garbage collection in C#
item.dc:creator: Jakub Chodounsky
item.content:encoded:
When you are programming, no matter the task on hand, you are manipulating some data. These are stored in basic types and objects and they live inside computer memory. Eventually, the memory fills up and you need to make more room for new data and discard the oldÂ one.

You can do it either by hand, like C and C++ programmers (used to) do, or use a languages with a mechanism that does it for you. In C# we are fortunate enough to have a garbage collector that takes care of ourÂ memory.

Basic concepts

In short, garbage collector tries to find objects that are no longer in use by the program and delete them fromÂ memory.

The first garbage collected language was LISP written by John McCarthyâ€Šâ€”â€Šone of the founders of artificial intelligenceâ€Šâ€”â€Šaround 1959. So the concept has been around for aÂ while.

When you have a garbage collector in place you are making a trade off of safe memory allocations and programmerâ€™s productivity for performance overhead. Garbage collected language will never be suitable for real-time critical applications like air traffic control, but you can get solid performance out of itâ€Šâ€”â€ŠIâ€™ve seen successful high frequency trading platforms written inÂ C#.

Garbage collection is not only responsible for cleaning the memory and compacting it, but also allocating newÂ objects.

.NET and CLR are making use of tracing garbage collector. That means that on every collection the collector figures out whether the object is used by tracing every object from stack roots, GC handles and staticÂ data.

Every object that could be traced is marked as live and at the end of tracing the ones without the mark are removed (swept) from the memory and it gets compacted. This is called a simple mark and sweep algorithm.

It gets a bit more complex than that but this is enough for having a simple mental model of whatâ€™s happening under theÂ hood.

If the garbage collector halts the program when running we call this event stop the world. That guarantees that no new objects are allocated during collection, but it also means that there will be a delay in our program. To minimise that disruption incremental and concurrent garbage collectors has been designed.

Incremental collection makes the pauses shorter and works in small increments and concurrent doesnâ€™t stop the program at all. For that you are paying with the overall longer collection time and the use of more CPU and memory resources than traditional stop theÂ world.

Generational collection

In 1984 David Ungar came up with a generational hypothesis that layed the foundations of GC that are in use theseÂ days.

Young objects die young. Therefore reclamation algorithm should not waste time on old objects.
Copying survivors is cheaper than scanningÂ corpses.

This hypothesis gave birth of the generational garbage collectorsâ€Šâ€”â€Šfirst used in Smalltalk and used in all modern platforms todayâ€Šâ€”â€ŠC# is not an exception.

The memory is divided into several generations based on the age of objects. The collection happens in the youngest generation and the surviving objects are promoted to the generation above.

In C# we have 3 generations:

  • Generation 0 is the youngest generation with short-lived objects in which the collection happens the most often. New objects are placed here with the exception of large objects that go straight to the Generation 2.
  • Generation 1 serves as a buffer between the short-lived and long-lived objects.
  • Generation 2 is the place for the long-lived objects and it gets collected lessÂ often.

When there is a collection over Generation 2 we call it full garbage collection as it goes through all objects in managedÂ memory.

To keep the balance between generations most modern platforms are using a hybrid approach of generational cycles (minor cycle) and some variation of full mark and sweep (majorÂ cycle).

The CLR automatically adjusts itself between not letting the used memory get too big and not letting the garbage collection take too much time by setting thresholds for new object allocation.

The collection gets triggered when

  • memory isÂ low,
  • threshold is exceededÂ or
  • GC.Collect is called manually.

When the collection is triggered every thread is suspended, so it canâ€™t allocate new memory, and the GC thread goes intoÂ action.

As you already know the collector uses static data to know whether the object is alive or not. As the static fields are kept in memory forever (until the AppDomain gets unloaded) this might lead to a common memory leak when it refers to a collection and you keep adding objects to the collection. The static field keeps the collection alive and all the objects inside alive as well. Be careful about that and possibly avoid the usage of static fields if youÂ can.

Characteristics

Modern garbage collectors have different characteristics and as with many things in programmingâ€Šâ€”â€Šdifferent trade offs. Based on the application requirements they could be tuned towards less interruptions and better user experience or maybe you want to run a fast server-side application thatÂ scales.

What characterizes a Garbage Collector?

  • Program throughput: CPU time spent collecting vs CPU time doing usefulÂ work.
  • GC throughput: amount of data the collector can clear per CPUÂ time.
  • Heap overhead: additional memory the collector produced during collection.
  • Pause times: time needed for collection.
  • Pause frequency: how often does garbage collection happen?
  • Pause distribution: short pauses vs long pauses, and how consistent the pausesÂ are.
  • Allocation performance: how much time does the new object allocation take? Is it predictable?
  • Concurrency: does the collector make use of multicore CPUs?
  • Scaling: can your GC handle largerÂ heaps?
  • Warmup time: can a collector adjust to the characteristics of your application? How long does it take toÂ adjust?

Configuration

You can influence the type and behavior of your application by setting garbage collection to a different type.

There are two major typesâ€Šâ€”â€Šworkstation and server. They could be configured by setting <gcServer enabled="true|false" /> element in your application configuration.

<configuration>
   <runtime>
       <gcServer enabled="true"/>
   </runtime>
</configuration>

The workstation setting is tuned for client-side applications. Low latency is preferred as you donâ€™t want your forms in WPF application become unresponsive during a long pause caused by garbage collection. In this mode it favours user experience and less CPUÂ usage.

On the other hand, the server configuration is designed for high throughput and scalability of server-side applications and it uses multiple dedicated threads for garbage collection with the highest priority. It is faster than workstation but that also comes with more CPU and memory usage. This configuration assumes that no other applications are running on the server and prioritise the GC threads accordingly. Also, it splits the managed heap into sections based on the number of CPUs. There is one special GC thread per CPU that takes care of the collection of its section. You can run this mode only on a computer with multipleÂ CPUs.

By default, the workstation GC mode isÂ active.

Another option you can choose is to use concurrent collection by using the <gcConcurrent enabled="true|false" />. It will give you more responsive application with less pause frequency andÂ time.

<configuration>
   <runtime>
       <gcConcurrent enabled="false"/>
   </runtime>
</configuration>

In concurrent mode, there will be an extra background thread that marks the objects alive when your application is executing its code. When it comes to collection, it will be faster as the set of dead objects has already beenÂ built.

The concurrency only affects the generation 2. Generation 0 and 1 will always be non-concurrent as they both finish fast and are not worth the extra overhead. When concurrent option is set, a dedicated thread will be used for collection.

To improve performance of several processes running side by side, you can try using workstation garbage collection with the concurrent collection disabled. This will lead to less context switching and therefore better performance.

Performance

The memory is divided into small object heap and large object heap. Large objects are the ones above 85 000 bytes and they go straight into the Generation 2.

In general, fewer objects on the managed heap is less work for garbage collector. That is applied especially to the large object heap that gets collected lessÂ often.

If you feel like GC causes you troubles there are various tools that you can use to debug itâ€Šâ€”â€Šmemory performance counter, WinDbg or tracing ETWÂ events.

Triggering collection manually with GC.Collect is usually more counterproductive than beneficial unless you really know what you are doing. It might help in certain situations when you want to release a lot of memory at once (e.g. a large dialog is closed and wonâ€™t be used again) â€“ but unless you have diagnosed a memory problem, donâ€™t goÂ there.

If you are calling GC.Collect manually too frequently you will certainly see a decrease of performance in your application.

When you get into situation where the latency of your application is criticalâ€Šâ€”â€Šlike in the middle of the high frequency trading decision loopâ€Šâ€”â€Šyou can set a low latency mode. This will put the GC into a low intrusive mode when it will become very conservative.

GCLatencyMode oldMode = GCSettings.LatencyMode;
System.Runtime.CompilerServices.RuntimeHelpers.PrepareConstrainedRegions();
try
{
    GCSettings.LatencyMode = GCLatencyMode.LowLatency;
    ...
}
finally
{
    GCSettings.LatencyMode = oldMode;
}

The collection of Generation 2 will be paused for the time in low latency mode. That leads to shorter and less frequent pause times and therefore decreased program latency. But that comes with the price that you might run out of memory if you are not careful. The best guideline is to keep those low latency sections as short as possible and donâ€™t allocate too many new objects, especially on the large heap. In this case you might want to call GC.Collect where appropriate to force the Generation 2 collection.

Donâ€™t forget that the latency mode is process wide, so if you are running multiple threads it will be applied to all ofÂ them.

Managed and unmanaged resources

In CLR all the code that is written is managed and it will be garbage collected. C# gets compiled into CIL and runs on top of CLR so all your C# code will be garbage collected.

That sounds easy enough until you need to use unmanaged resources.

And you will use them on almost daily basis as these are database connections, COM interops, network and file streams and many others. Unmanaged resources are not garbage collected and you need to free them from your memory byÂ hand.

If you write a type that uses an unamanged resource youÂ should

  • implement the dispose patternÂ and
  • provide a mechanism to free the resource in case consumer forgets to callÂ Dispose.

The basic implementation of a dispose pattern with the use of SafeHandle could lookÂ like

public class DisposableResourceHolder : IDisposable
{
    private SafeHandle resource;
public DisposableResourceHolder()
    {
        this.resource = ...
    }
public void Dispose()
    {
        Dispose(true);
        GC.SuppressFinalize(this);
    }
protected virtual void Dispose(bool disposing)
    {
        if (disposing)
        {
            if (resource != null) resource.Dispose();
        }
    }
}

To free the resource you can use Object.Finalize or SafeHandles. For more details check out Cleaning up Unmanaged Resources.

As a consumer of a type with unmanaged resource always use the usingÂ pattern.

using (var s = new StreamReader("file.txt"))
{
  ...
  s.Close();
}

How can you tell the object needs to be disposed? It implements the IDisposable interface. Some static analysis tools can help you notice the cases where you might have forgotten to dispose yourÂ objects.

What about other languages?

The first versions of Ruby used a simple mark and sweep technique which isnâ€™t the best performer but it was simple for the authors of C-extensions to write native extensions. That simplicity was the key to Rubyâ€™s growth in the beginning and took it where it is these days. Generational collection was introduced in Ruby 2.1 (current version is 2.4) to improve the throughput of programsâ€Šâ€”â€Šquite late in terms of language maturity. After that Ruby 2.2 introduced incremental marking which addresses long pause times by running the GC in short increments.

Programmers in C++ donâ€™t have any garbage collection and they need to do memory management by hand. There are techniques to make that easierâ€Šâ€”â€Šsmart pointer are now part of the C++ 11 standard and are a tool that automatically deletes memory from the heap. Smart pointer can be implemented with reference counting that ensures that the object is deleted as soon as it is no longer neededâ€Šâ€”â€Šas opposed to tracing garbage collection when the unused object waits for the next cycle of collection.

Java is very similar to C# and uses tracing generational garbage collectionâ€Šâ€”â€Šthe heap is structured to a young generation (eden, S0 and S1), old generation and permanent generation. GC uses minor and major cycles to clean the generations and promote objects from one to the other. Both the collections of young and old generations are the â€œstop the worldâ€ event so all the threads are suspended until they finish. There are different types of collectors on JVMâ€Šâ€”â€Šserial, parallel, concurrent mark and sweep and its replacement G1 in JavaÂ 7.

Python doesnâ€™t use tracing garbage collection but a reference counting with periodical cycle detection to solve the case of two dead objects pointing to each other. But as opposed to classic reference counting it combines it with the generational approach and uses the reference count instead of the mark and sweep algorithm. It doesnâ€™t deal with memory fragmentation but tries to avoid it with allocating objects on different pools ofÂ memory.

In Javascript there isnâ€™t a unified approach to garbage collection. It is in hands of browser vendors and they do it differentlyâ€Šâ€”â€ŠInternet 6 and 7 used reference counting garbage collectors for DOM objects. From 2012 almost all modern browsers are shipped with tracing mark and sweep algorithms with some extra improvementsâ€Šâ€”â€Šgenerations, incremental collection, concurrency and parallelism.

Conclusion

C# and languages on top of CLR are garbage collected. They use generational garbage collection with 3 generations and an advanced tracing mark and sweep algorithm to figure out which objects are stillÂ alive.

You can change the characteristics of the collector by changing to a server or workstation mode and setting up a concurrency mode.

Most of the times triggering garbage collection manually is not a good idea unless you really know what you are doing. And in cases where latency is important you can use latency mode to increase your program throughput and eliminate pauses.

Lastly, there are unmanaged resources like file streams, network, database connections that you need to take a special care of. Most of the times youâ€™ll be implementing and using the IDisposable pattern so you donâ€™t cause any memory leaks in your application.

  • Garbage collection onÂ MSDN
  • Garbage collection on Wikipedia
  • Tracing garbage collection
  • Mike Hearn on Modern garbage collection
  • David Ungar on Generation Scavenging

item.title: Programming newsletters are the future
item.dc:creator: Jakub Chodounsky
item.content:encoded:
Part of being a great software developer is keeping up to date, but there are a few problems withÂ that.

Every day you are bombarded with tons of information and news from all the different sourcesâ€Šâ€”â€ŠTwitter, HackerNews, Medium, and all theÂ others.

Your build is running a bit slow today, so you decide to have a look at Twitter, maybe read something about the new C# 7 features. You just want to sharpen your saw as highly effective developers tend toÂ do.

But the bottomless timeline is designed to keep you on the site longer. To distract you from your real reason why you thereâ€Šâ€”â€Što educate yourself.

Ads, link-baits, unrelated posts and suddenly you find yourself half an hour later watching some cat video, engaged in political discussion, or day dreaming after reading some startup success story. And the focus isÂ gone.

Curation is hard. Trust me. Iâ€™ve been curating programming newsletters for a few years and itâ€™s a skill you need to learn. When you subscribe to an email newsletter someone else does it forÂ you.

Most current content media are designed for instant consumption. If are not there, you will miss the post. And what if it is a truly revolutionary? This creates an unpleasant fear of missingÂ out.

Thatâ€™s why you find yourself checking the streams multiple times a day and you might even not realise it. It becomes part of your subconscious habits. Ctrl+T f a c eÂ â€¦ what the hell am IÂ doing?

You feel busy, you feel important, you feel productive. The hard true is that you are not. You are just distorting your attention.

With newsletters you receive them in your inbox and you read them when it suits you (you turned email notifications off, right?). Nothing to be missed. No constant fear and no ever-present multi-tasking. Thatâ€™s why I love them and I think you shouldÂ too.

Turn off distractions. Get your sanity back. Read programming newsletters.

If you liked this check out the newsletters I put together everyÂ week:

  • C# Digest is great for anyÂ .NET developers as it stays general enough to be useful for any ASP.NET developer as well as WPF or plain backendÂ one.
  • Programming Digest gives you an idea of whatâ€™s happening in different programming communities. Good complement to yourÂ niche.
  • React Digest is focused on front-end web development with React and the stackÂ around.
  • Elixir Digest has everything important about Phoenix framework and Elixir language.
  • Machine Learning Digest is the best for getting your feet wet with artificial intelligence, data science, and machine learningÂ topics.

There are heaps of other great newsletters and if you follow one, please tell me in the comments below. Iâ€™d love to check themÂ out.
